definition: to go abroad (old)

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
ocean/vast/foreign/silver dollar or coin
to make a fool of oneself

sentences.english: He cut a poor figure on a public occasion.
sentences.chinese: 他在大庭廣衆中大出洋相。

sentences.english: You ought ton't do expressions in class.
sentences.chinese: 上課無所不能做鬼臉，出洋相。

sentences.english: And I resolved not to think of going abroad any more, but to settle at home according to my father's desire.
sentences.chinese: 我決定不再起出洋的念頭，聽從父親的話，守在家裏。

sentences.english: When training with the nunchaku at first, be prepared to look like a bad comedy routine.
sentences.chinese: 開始學習雙節棍時，要有出洋相的心理準備。

sentences.english: When they make spectacles of themselves.
I don't look silly in public. That's the difference.
sentences.chinese: 我不會在公從面前出洋相，這就是區別。

sentences.english: It’s always fun to see people make fools of themselves.
sentences.chinese: 有人出洋相，總是很好玩的。

sentences.english: From the mid-Ching onwards, large numbers of emigrants went abroad from Fujian and Guangdong.
sentences.chinese: 清中葉以降，大量的閩粵移民出洋。

sentences.english: Please don't make a scene in public places.
sentences.chinese: 請不要在公共場合大吵大鬧出洋相。

sentences.english: It amused him to see people make fools of themselves.
sentences.chinese: 看到人們出洋相把他逗笑了。

sentences.english: You have ton't do expressions in class.
sentences.chinese: 上課不能做鬼臉，出洋相。

sentences.english: Medium to full bodied, showing fruit characters of plums and dark cherries.
sentences.chinese: 酒體豐滿，勾勒出洋李與黑櫻桃的果味。

definition: Fuzhou Naval College, a.k.a. Foochow Naval Dockyard School, set up in 1866 by the Qing dynasty
steamboat
foreigner/Westerner
the Qing dynasty equivalent of the Foreign Office
Shen Baozhen (1820-1879), Qing Minister of the Navy, founded Fuzhou Naval College 船政學堂|船政学堂[Chuan2 zheng4 Xue2 tang2] in 1866
Penang Pulau (Island), Malaysia
foreign affairs (in Qing times)/foreign learning
Qing government (1644-1911)
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
Li Hung-chang or Li Hongzhang (1823-1901), Qing dynasty general, politician and diplomat
Westerner employed in Qing China (as professor or military advisor etc)
Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
the first modern Chinese library established in 1898 by William A.P. Martin 丁韙良|丁韪良, becoming the foundation for Peking University library
the Qing court (as government of China)
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
comprador
